text: [Music]
I more or less agree with John Lewis
although I think he may have overstated
the
case but it is very difficult
to
believe that in some of the crowds that
have been attracted
by by McCain and by Sarah Palin
that there are not a lot of prejudiced
people in that crowd and that that
prejudice I I don't think McCain himself
I'm not trying to say he's Prejudice
whether he's done all that he could to
stop that I don't know Sarah Palin as
far as I'm aware has done
[Music]
nothing well we've gone down there I
went down with one or two people with me
and with General
Abrams
uh who had two officers with
him
and we didn't know what Governor Wallace
was going to do except we thought he was
going to stand in the door and we
doubted very much he was going to give
in uh although we knew he did not want
violence the question was whether he
could prevent
it and uh actually I didn't get much
sleep the night
before there was a a reporter who had a
nervous breakdown we had to get him to a
hospital and things of that
kind and I went out in the morning and
picked up uh Vivian
Malone and James Hood John door and I
went out
and picked the two of them up and
birmingam drove him
back to Tuscaloosa
on the way back Bobby called we were in
a border patrol car with
radio connections with Washington Bobby
called and he said what are you going to
say to the Governor Wallace and I said I
don't really
know uh but and he said well the
president wants you to make him look
foolish I said fine if you got any ideas
that's how to do that he said oh don't
worry Nick you'll do fine and so we went
on to the university I had done a couple
of things that I was pleased
with one was that I said I would go
confront Governor
Wallace without the two black students I
didn't know saw no reason why they
should be
insulted by the
governor and one of the things that I
find moving even
today was that the US attorney in
Birmingham and the US Marshall in
Birmingham both political
appointees in the Deep
South insisted on going with me that it
was part of their job too and that was a
very courageous thing in the Alabama of
that
time and it was hot as
Hades and so we walked up to the door
that they
designated and I got in the first words
I think and the governor wanted to shut
me up and we went back and forth a
little bit and I haven't to this day I
I've seen it on television but I can't
remember what I
said except I remember a couple of
things that I liked one was I annoyed
the governor when I said I don't know
what the purpose of this big show is
it's just two students qualified
students trying to get into the
university to which they're entitled to
be
admitted and I don't see any reason for
this show that he didn't like
that and uh
so they tried to put mics on me the
media did I wouldn't have them but there
was no worry about that he had a mic in
every pocket of his suit and trousers
and jacket and round his neck and every
other place so there wasn't much danger
of my not being known and then I had
arranged with Frank Rose the
president that when he rejected us as we
expected that I would take I would take
viven and John dor would take Jimmy Hood
to their donator
rooms so we didn't leave the campus
which I thought was
important and at that time
uh told the president to time to
federalize the guard put it in federal
service the Alabama National Guard which
was uh
commanded that time by General
Graham who knew the governor very well
and
so I remember going back to telling
General Abrams who was had also slept
all night in his SE sear sucker suit
and I said if we had to nationalize the
guard and one of the lieutenant colonel
with him said to the general I assume
this will be to General Abrams I assume
this will be uniforms sir and Abrams who
always had a big cigar in his mouth said
nah he said I don't think so Graham
knows who I
am and so the guard got put in federal
service then Abrams came to me about an
hour
later said General Graham has talked to
the governor they were quite friendly
Graham and the governor and the governor
wants to go back to be confronted by the
military under Graham's
command and if so he will make a brief
speech and he will leave and he will
leave all of his law enforcement people
with instructions to keep order and that
seemed like a hell of a good deal to
[Music]
me well it's interesting to me I mean I
I felt I've been down at Old Miss where
we had a really bad Riot with people
killed and a lot of people wounded and
and terrible
Riot uh and I felt that we that was a
failure on our part
I'm not sure in retrospect that it was I
think you had to have an incident of
that kind and that dramatic thing with
the Army coming in 22,000 strong Oxford
Mississippi but I think you had to have
it and people had to see what was in
fact being
faced and I think in retrospect that
that was that was a necessary part of
the whole civil rights movement that one
such incident should
occur and I think that in a funny way
Governor Wallace saw it the same
way he didn't want that kind of an
incident to happen in Alabama Governor
Barnett did not get any credit for
trying to keep James murth out of the
University of Mississippi and causing a
riot people that was not something that
people in Mississippi had really
contemplated
well we didn't have cell phones then so
that was lucky I know I just told her I
had to go out of town that I was going
down to Oxford she knew what was going
on there but
uh I was lucky enough in my life to
marry a remarkable woman so I could tell
her where I was doing and what I was
doing and she didn't try to lecture me
or deter me you have to understand that
Vivian Malon was a very as so many of
the young blacks were she was a
exceptional
person and very Courageous
one as were James hood and James
Mur but I said you know you've got to
sit down in the cafeteria and eat
because you're going to have to do that
and the sooner we get over that the
better and she said okay and so she did
she sat by herself at a
table and almost immediately two other
girl students came over and sat down
with her white
students now I think they were both from
the north to tell the truth but that
didn't make very much difference it was
something had happened we had we had
crossed the threshold when that
happened but one of the differences
between University of Mississippi then
not today but then and the University of
Alabama
is that the president of the University
of Alabama Frank Rose wanted the
university integrated and that was a
very important
factor he knew Bobby Kennedy
slightly and he was a source of
information for us and a source of
support
[Music]
throughout you can think of the riot at
Old Miss you can think of
the the four girls killed in the
Birmingham bombing
you can think of the situation Voting
Act with
Selma with Sheriff
Clark but some of the things they did
they
had young kids were
demonstrating really kids I mean 10
years old 12 years old and the police
chasing them with fire hoses and chasing
them way down the road and and maybe
three miles something like that and then
letting them Escape
and then the Martian Selma trying to go
across the Pettis bridge but just see
people who were
unarmed doing asserting a constitutional
right it was a sheriff Clark was a
perfect foil I mean the idea of using
carriot prods and hoses on people like
that
horses it it and that was going by
television into rooms all around around
the country and I think the American
people just said enough is enough stop
[Music]
it which we should have said long before
[Music]
